(But things only seem to change color sometimes + the squares don't always line up perfectly). Any remixes with solutions welcome (I'm tagging @jsh for some help).

title: Conditions for...?
description:
I began by thinking about the question "what kind of secret would I like to reveal?"

I'm not sure if I share the right amount of information in the instructions + while playing. I want those playing to discover the features, though is there enough to start from? How is the timing?

[intentionally minimal notes for hidden factor!]
instructions:
Press the green flag.

After that, move the mouse around and see what you can discover if you press the mouse in different parts of the stage.

Can you resist the urge to look inside for hints?

title: Three of a Kind
description:
I was recently in Las Vegas for my grandmother's 90th birthday party. (She's very adventurous!) While there, I was stunned by the number of slot machines—I think it left a deep aesthetic impression on me. And so when I saw today's prompt (Day 18 of Getting Unstuck), it made me think of these games of chance! The structure of the prompt and the structure of my lived experiences collided to produce this creation!
My sound effects selections don't sound right to me, but I wasn't entirely what would be better (and where to find it). If you have any audio recommendations, please let me know—I would be very grateful! (Update: I switched from gong on spin-click to computer beeps, which seems less blarghy.)
instructions:
Press the green flag, then spin to play.
Can you get three of a kind?

title: Unstuck Day 18
description: I think I am getting the hang of things:-)
instructions: To play with the little bug, just click the green flag.

title: Puzzle
description:
This project was created for Day 18 of Getting Unstuck. I've always loved puzzle games, so I thought I would try my hand at making one today. Conclusion: it's harder than it seems!  

I thought I would "keep it simple" and avoid clones with the project, but I had some major regrets due to the amount of work to keep the nearly-identical sprites in sync with each other. Lesson learned: use clones when you can!

Music: 4bstr4ck3r, "Random Effect"
instructions: Solve the puzzle to reveal the secret!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 18 — Guessing Game
description:
Reflection

For today's Getting Unstuck, I use the AND block to sanitize the input. Players should only be able to select a number between 1 and 100. Should the player enter in a number outside of this range, or anything else that isn't a pure number, Scratch Cat informs them that the input is invalid, and players are not penalized.
instructions:
Welcome to the Guessing Game!!

Choose a number between 1 and 100 until you guess the correct number. The less number of guesses it takes you, the better the prize.

Only six levels, but you can do more.

title: Getting Unstuck #18: Reveal the secret
description:
Scratch project was created as activity #18 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #18 Challenge: Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.
instructions: Press the green flag and follow the instructions!

title: Unstuck 18 Multiple conditions
description: I saw this challenge as an opportunity to build upon and improve one of my previous projects, involving game levels. Specifically, in addition to incorporating "multiple condition checking," I wanted to get more practice using clones as "game treasures" and "game features" (in this case platforms. I learned that "delete this clone" is necessary in order for global counters to be used in the "when I start as a clone" block. I am motivated to do some more reading about exactly what happens to scratch variables when clones are created. I didn't have time to fancy up the game ending, including stopping the display of clones at the end of the game.
instructions:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

Collect all the treasures and keys to reveal the secret.

title: Unstuck: Day 18, Secret Revealed V2
description:
This project is for Getting Unstuck challenge day 18, reveal something by user interaction.
This one is an update to my first submitted project today, adding the feature of changing the colors.
instructions:
What color are the 3 columns of circles? Click the button to reveal the secret! Try different color combinations and see which create a more effective illusion.
This project is an example of a Munker illusion, in which bands of different colors are shown to affect each other in surprising ways. I came across a version of it online here https://twitter.com/NovickProf/status/1019592963259691008. 
It's hard to believe your eyes!

title: If you dare ... (Getting Unstuck Day 18)
description:
This is my sixth Getting Unstuck project (two of them can be found on my other account @PinkyPepper).

I remixed an old project and turned it into a puzzle game. I would have liked to make a real escape room, but I gave myself a time constraint today. I used a list again, because I learned more about using lists yesterday. My daughter tested my project and found a bug, which was easy to solve. If you find another one, please let me know.
instructions:
This is a puzzle game. Can you reveal the surpise? Take a chance and look around in the dark  if you dare ...

I made this for Day 18 of Getting Unstuck. Todays challenge:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

That is all it took for inspiration for this project apparently. No city workers were harmed in the making of this project nor did any end up in space. :)

Another wild ride. Click the flag and enjoy I very rarely do animations. However, Getting Unstuck has had me creating them and I have had fun doing them.

title: Day 18: I like to eat . . .
description:
I created this project during the "mouse over" challenge, but couldn't get it to work that day.  Fixed that (yay!!)
When the surprise was revealed, I wanted to make the appearance of sprites more "showy" and to play a certain song :)  Had trouble changing the size of sprites when grow and shrink were clicked.  Also wanted to introduce a chomping sound, but it glitched.  When instructions were coded to do something fancy, such as turn right and then left, the sprite followed the first instruction but not the next ones in the series. 
I wanted the intro script to run completely before the scroll over options began, so I introduced the space bar (in addition to green flag and broadcast). I suspect there is conflict with the "Event" blocks as with an earlier challenge, but not sure. 
Suggestions for debugging and alternate/more efficient use of code are welcome.
instructions:
Press the green flag and you may find out what Nano likes to eat!

Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

title: Memory
description:
I started the project three times because I kept missing the objective of today's challenge. And even this one is barely hits. I removed the ands and ors and used a not condition to make the program understand that the two cards are the same. I got stuck several times, mainly because I needed to figure how to randomize the lists. I did a list with numbers from 1 to 20 and then randomly it puts them in other two lists, deleting the number so it can't be used again. So card n.1 (the cat) are in position list1 n.1 and list2 n.1. Card n.2 (the crab) are in position list1 n.2 and list2 n.2. Headache? :P
Every clone has a private variable (remember, the sprite variables are also clone variables) with a progressive number, so every time the user clicks on a card, it's possible to know what it is looking for its number in the lists.

Fun facts: the whole game is inspired by an old (early eighties) quiz show, named BIS, where the cells were small slide projectors' screens controlled by wire from a console.

Credits: map by Tubs and hands+vinyl by Mbdortmund, from Wikipedia
instructions: It's the classic memory game! Click on the cards and search for matches. A riddle will be shown after you remove the cards.

title: Unstuck 18 Multiple conditions (v2)
description:
Update v2:
-I think I fixed the problems with not displaying the "game complete" message correctly. I spent some time reading the scratch wiki to better understand how clones work, which has been a challenge for me. I made some changes based on what I learned.
-cleaned up leftover platform clones at end of game.
-added a "this way" sprite to show how to get to the next level.

I saw this challenge as an opportunity to build upon and improve one of my previous projects, involving game levels. Specifically, in addition to incorporating "multiple condition checking," I wanted to get more practice using clones as "game treasures" and "game features" (in this case platforms. I learned that "delete this clone" is necessary in order for global counters to be used in the "when I start as a clone" block. I am motivated to do some more reading about exactly what happens to scratch variables when clones are created. I didn't have time to fancy up the game ending, including stopping the display of clones at the end of the game.
instructions:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

Collect all the treasures and keys to reveal the secret.

title: Unstuck 18 Pickup Sticks *Draft*
description:
I got stuck so many times creating this project. It was a lot of fun to figure out how to get each piece to work!

I worked through a number of issues with layers, but can't figure out how to place a stick that is moved from the middle of the remaining pile back to it's same location after it is moved to the front. I have to rethink the system of using variables to track the layers.

This might work best abandoning the layers altogether and using some sort of physical controller (makey makey, scratchbit, micro:bit?) and collabroation between one person moving the mouse and another operating the mouse click, press, and release.
instructions:
Did you ever play the game pick up sticks? You had to move a stick off a pile without any other stick moving.

I've been working all day on having the user move the top stick off the pile, but I'm running into trouble managing layers. I put it back together but now it delays when you move the seventh stick. Keep trying and I'll come back to it later to try to fix it.

If you separate all the sticks, you will see a surprise!

I still need to add audio effects, but wanted to get it posted.

title: Unstuck Day 18
description: I have only coded for sums from 2 to 12 as if it were two dice. If I was to extend the range of numbers I would need to add another If/Then and Operator to show the resulting sum.  I could do that as a variable that shows on the screen but I didn't know how to show it as Sprite or Costume size numbers
instructions: click the green flag and have Cat add numbers

title: Getting Unstuck #18
description:
Getting Unstuck day 18.
When this email arrived I was thinking about one of my favourite childrens' books, Harquin, the Fox who went down to went down to the valley. In this program, if it's night, and the squire's not about, Harquin will come out and look around. If either of these conditions is not met he'll (eventually) go back to his burrow. 
There is no surprise in this project. I was so intent on doing something using Harquin that I didn't really read the prompt. There's a lesson there.
I enjoyed using the vector editor, and suspect I'll be using it again.
I think I have the timings about right; Harquin seems to appear and disappear often enough.
instructions: Press the green flag.

title: Critical Hit? (Unstuck 18)
description:
For such a simple prompt, this one really challenged me. Since I didn't know where to start, I approached this the same way when working with other material, and just started "doing stuff." Once I put a few blocks together, this idea came together.

Right now, there's no real end to the game and I'm open to suggestions. I'm struggling with having the scripts stop when Hit Points equal zero or less. I've tried a lot of variations with the "stop all" block, and haven't had any success - will try again soon.
instructions:
Click on the Beholder to "roll" your d20 and see if you can get a critical hit for 2x damage -- before its hit points reach 0.

This is a work in progress (see below).

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 18
description:
This is my project for Day 18 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. As the challenge goes on, it becomes increasingly difficult to find a solution to the proposed problem. I think I've made a nice game even if I have to say it's a hard to win. However, the difficulty can be adjusted by changing the speed of the figures or the speed of the ball.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

English: 3 geometric figures travels in space. If you hit the square you will gain 1 point, otherwise you'll lose a point. Try to get a score above 3 (it seems easy but it's not, trust me :P) and you will have access to the surprise. 
How to throw the ball? Press the SPACE key and point the mouse in the direction you want the ball to be launched.


Italian translation: 3 figure geometriche viaggiano nello spazio. Se colpisci il quadrato otterrai 1 punto, altrimenti perderai un punto. Cerca di ottenere un punteggio superiore a 3 (sembra facile ma non lo è, fidati di me: P) e avrai accesso alla sorpresa.
Come lanciare la palla? Premi il tasto SPAZIO e punta il mouse nella direzione in cui vuoi che venga lanciata la palla.

title: Unstuck Day 18 - Mood Survey
description:
I had a tough time today. I had most of this project done in the morning then went to see Hamilton. When I logged into Scratch this evening, my project was gone.I did the best I could making it a second time. The tallies don't seem to be working, so I need to fix that. But that's for another day. BTW - If you have a chance to see Hamilton, it's fantastic! 

It sounds like I need cloud variables in order for the tallies to remain. I don't believe I have the ability to make them. So feel free to do this several times and change your anwers each time.

title: challenge18EscapeRoom
description: This project turned out way more complicated than I first intended it to be. I used the "and" operator block twice: once to check that all the coefficients of the balanced chemical equation were correct, and once to set a range for the answer to a gram calculation.I used the "or" key to take into account the different ways the user could enter the limiting reagent - by name or formula. I made the key sprites myself, from pictures. The sounds are all in public domain, except for the door unlocked sound, which was recorded by Mike Koenig and found at SoundBible.com.
instructions: This is an escape room. The clues to escape are chemistry questions. Click the green flag to begin.

title: Two Dice Game
description:
Unstuck Challenge 18: Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

This project is designed for 7th Grade Math Probability Unit: compound event. Possible remix idea is to simulate "Two Dice Sum" or "Two Dice Product".

title: Little gold miner
description:
At first, I didn't know what to do today.Then I realized, that I could do something interesting by using the pen blocks.
So, I decided to create a game where you can find different hidden things. I used clones for the treasures and when they are close, they are making a sound that help us to find them.

I'd like to add more things to find, music  and another way to improve the use of pen blocks.
instructions:
Help the gold miner to find precious metals or other things before time  runs out.
Press the play button to start and follow the directions.
Mouse to move.
Space and mouse button to dig.
You've got 120 secs.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
My first late submission! Was out all day yesterday, so a quick and dirty project for today.

Wanted to make a puzzle where combinations of keys could be pressed together to solve a puzzle. This was the quickest version I could make. If I find more time I may add more options and Scratch Cat secrets!
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 18

Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

title: Getting Unlocked
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 18
by Massimo Marletta

The user must guess a number satisfying all the 3 secret criteria.
Each of the orange block will move as one criterion is satisfied.
instructions:
* You have to guess a number which satisfies some secret criteria.

* Set your guess with the green buttons (the left one decrease and the right one increase the values showed in the display).

* Click on the key to check if your number is the secret one.

Each of the tree locks (the orange blocks on the right) will move and became blue (indicating you have unlocked a part of the mechanism) if your guess satisfies a criterion. Only if your guess satisfies ALL the criteria the mechanism will be completely unlocked!
(for example if the secret number is 10, the first lock could be unlocked if your guess is multiple of 2, the second if your guess if multiple of 5, ...).

title: Virtual Flower
description:
I was able to get this project to work, but I don't think I've got the conditions quite right - I think it's just picking up on the touching the pot bottom and that's all it needs to do.  I think I need to work on it more to figure out how to introduce another condition.

Given more time, I'd also move the water and food to sprinkle onto the flowers and then move back. I would also add variables to monitor hunger, thirst, and light.

I got the original idea from Scratch's Virtual Pet project - from a set of Scratch Coding Cards that I just received. https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237145343/#editor
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin.

Provide just the right condition for the flowers to grow to their fullest...

Hint: Answer using only the object name (i.e. - phone, not "a phone")

title: Logic - Getting Unstuck Day 18
description: I started down this path and I think I got too far into it to stop.
instructions:
An interesting logic puzzle. 
Click the green flag to start the project.  and click on the top row of balls to change the colour. 
Depending on the logic the balls in the second row will change colours.  
When the balls in the last row match you have unlocked the background!!  
It can be easy depending on the ball to match. or very challenging!!

title: DAY 18 GetCHEETOS
description: I was trying really hard to do something fabulous today but ended up just doing this. I still don't get what a lot of people are doing, BUT, I made another list (which I'm new at) so that's cool.
instructions:
First goal is to get the cheetos 5 times. You can only move if you use the up AND right arrow at the same time, or the down AND left arrow.
Once you get a score of 5, you will get one of 3 secrets. If you get the secret password, then you get a surprise!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18 - conditionals
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 18: conditionals.

For this project I revisited an earlier game I made for Day 9. I figured out a way to use conditionals to randomly place the food, plus used conditionals to determine whether the player was successful or not.
instructions:
Press the green flag to get started. Your objective is to gather as many food pellets as possible to take to the feeding center.

Use the arrow keys to move the ant through the maze.

Red pellets = kills the ant and stops all action
Yellow/green = +1 point
Purple/pink = -1 point

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 18 Reflection:
This is really simple, but I got to try a few different operators that I hadn't used before.  MsNykorchuk5's project has more riddles, which is what I'd like to figure out how to do.
I think the and/or/not operators are helpful, but I have to think more about when to use them.  A lot of times the if/then blocks seem to work just as well, if not better.  But I am not a very advanced Scratch user - I'm sure they have their uses that I don't quite understand yet!
instructions: Click on the green flag and see if you can solve the riddle.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
Inspiration came from Day 18 of Getting Unstuck asking me to use the and block in a conditional statement. I decided to follow the example of some early 8-bit games where the player had to collect objects to get to the next level.
I used the pacman from an earlier project and used the backpack to move it across.
To improve this project I would add more objects to collect, perhaps using cloning to do it efficiently. I'd also like to add more levels.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to start.
Use the arrow keys to control the pacman.
Avoid the red lines.
Collect the three items and make your way to the rainbow to finish the game.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 18
description:
The challenge for day 18 of Getting Unstuck is: "Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed."

I used the "or" block for the first clue because there are three correct possibilities.  I used the "and" block for the combinations of 2 and 3 correct items.

Reflection/Call for help:  I have spent close to two hours trying to figure out how to only broadcast one message at a time and I cannot figure it out!  When you click and hold down on a correct item it will display the previous response.  If there is a way to make it so no extra "say" bubbles appear? If so can you please remix it and show me (or explain why)? Thanks!
Oh boy... the above happens when you are looking inside... when you run it from the project page, my "no" message doesn't appear! HELP!
instructions: Scratch is planning a trip to a mystery location.  He only needs to bring 3 of the items shown.  Click an item to find out whether or not Scratch will put it in his car.  Once you figure out the three necessary items, Scratch will tell you where he is going!

title: Dance with letters
description:
Today's prompt was to make a project using some logical operators "and, or, not" to reveal a secret. The prompt was too wide and all it came in my mind were logic puzzles, but I wanted to do something more artistic.

The inspiration came from a video that I watched today about an installation at Artechouse, where people were immersed in a sea of letters and could interact with them by moving their bodies.

I made a first version pretty quickly but then I realized that I wasn't using the logical operators and I needed a secret to reveal. I got stuck, so I went for a walk. When I came back I had the idea of using the letters to reveal a word. The project got much more complicated but I learned more about clones and I'm pretty satisfied with the final result.

Enjoy!

PS: I've just realized that the prompt for day 19 is about clones! Now I have to make a different one! :)
instructions:
Click the green flag, make sure your webcam is on and... dance until you find the "secret" message!

To fully enjoy this project, get far from the screen and use all of your body to move the letters around.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 18
description: I used sensory blocks to send broadcasts and help the bug navigate around the screen. I needed to create global variables for the program so that the bug could send a signal to stop all sprites, change the background, and end the game.
instructions: Find the combination that works! Use the up, down, left, and right arrow keys to navigate the bug around the page. If the bug is sitting on top of the button for a few seconds, it will change color. Find the correct combination of button colors to win the game.
